Hi Arnold,
 
Very interesting. Was there any particular reason why the older tsuba
are smaller ? 
 
I have come up with 4 ideas
 
1. Maybe the swords were shorter, so had a smaller tsuba ? (unlikely
considering the Nambokucho monsters)
 
2. People had smaller hands back then, therefore requiring a smaller
tsuba ? (doubtful in my opinion)
 
3. The swords were better balanced at that time, think Kamakura etc,
therefore required less tsuba for balance ? (this is my favorite at the
moment together with the last one)
 
4. Since the swords were used on horseback with one arm, they had to be
light, ergo a small tsuba.
 
- Matt

Hi:
What an interesting question! I think that as a general rule the notion
of size and value, other things being equal, except in the restricted
situation of a daisho perfectly matched, but now separated pair, is
really
not an operational comparison. Tsuba size choices of the artisan were
determined by the parameters of the blade and koshirae appropriate to
the
period of initial manufacture. What make tsuba interesting and desirable
is how close the fit is what it ought to be for the time of manufacture.
If one follows Sasano sensei, for example, with respect to the earliest
tosho tsuba, the early ones were small and the later ones as a rule were
larger. Even though the designs might be quite similar, the criterion of
originality and probable scarcity ought to yield a significantly higher
price for the older but smaller piece. Mutatis mutandis the same
argument
holds for tsuba of different types and periods. How close the fit
between
the piece at hand and the ideal type is probably the main determinant of
value. For a short answer I do not believe that there is a correlation
merely between size and market value. My two cents worth anyway.  

Arnold Frenzel
afrenzel@...

> also when is a tsuba considered to be of wakizashi or katana size ?
and
